Class IntegerList

java.lang.Object
IntegerList
public class IntegerList extends Object
The IntegerList class implements a growable array of integers. Like an array, it contains elements that can be accessed using an integer index. However, the size of a IntegerList can grow as needed to accommodate adding items after the IntegerList has been created.

    The internal array into which the elements of the list are stored.

  • Constructor Details

    • IntegerList

      public IntegerList()
      Constructs an empty list so that its internal data array has capacity of 10.

    • IntegerList

      public IntegerList(int initialCapacity)
      Constructs and empty list with the specified initial capacity.
      Parameters:

  • Method Details

    • addElement

      public void addElement(int newValue)
      Adds the specified element to the end of this list, increasing its size by one.

      If adding the new element will fill the internal array to its maximum capacity, the array is resized before the insertion. The capacity is doubled, a new array of the updated size is created, and all existing elements are copied into it. This ensures that there is enough space to accommodate the new element without exceeding the array's bounds.

      Parameters:
      newValue - the element to be added

    • clear

      public void clear()
      Removes all of the elements from this list. The list will be empty after this call. The capacity will still be the same.

    • display

      public void display()
      Prints all elements of the list on a single line, separated by a single space. A newline character is added after the final element.

    • duplicate

      public IntegerList duplicate()
      Returns a new IntegerList instance containing the same elements and capacity as this list. The internal data of the new list is independent from that of the original, so changes to one list do not affect the other.
      Returns:
      a new list with the same contents as this one

    • find

      public int find(int value)
      Returns the index of the first occurrence of the specified element in this list, or -1 if this list does not contain the element.
      Parameters:
      value - element to search for
      Returns:
      the index of the first occurrence of the specified element in this list, or -1 if this list does not contain the element

    • getAverage

      public double getAverage()
      Returns the average of the numbers stored in the list.

      Assumption: At least one number exists in the list when this method is called.

      Returns:
      the real average of the numbers in the list

    • getCapacity

      public int getCapacity()
      Returns the current capacity of this list.
      Returns:
      the current capacity (the length of its internal data array)

    • getElementAt

      public int getElementAt(int index)
      Access an element from the list given an index.

      Assumption: When this method is called, a valid index is passed 0 to size-1.

      Parameters:
      index - the index of the element in the list to be accessed
      Returns:
      the element at that index

    • getSize

      public int getSize()
      Returns the number of elements in this list.
      Returns:
      the number of elements in this list

    • isEmpty

      public boolean isEmpty()
      Tests if this list has no elements.
      Returns:
      true if and only if this list has no elements, that is, its size is zero; false otherwsie.

    • isEqual

      public boolean isEqual(IntegerList otherList)
      Compares this list with the specified otherList for equality. Returns true if both lists have the same length and contain the same integer elements in the same order.
      Parameters:
      otherList - the list to compare with this list
      Returns:
      true if the two lists are equal in size and content; false otherwise

    • reverse

      public void reverse()
      Reverses the order of elements in this list in place. After calling this method, the element at index i will be moved to index n-1-i, where n is the size of the list.

    • setElementAt

      public void setElementAt(int index, int newValue)
      Replaces the element at the specified position in this list with the specified element. It is assumed that when this method is called, a valid index is passed 0 to size-1.
      Parameters:
      index - the specified index
      newValue - what the element is to be set to
